overview_of_class: Blackface has a long history in theatrical performance. In 18th-century Europe it took on new importance in the representation of empires and depictions of enslaved people. In 19th-century America it became imbricated into the new genre of blackface minstrelsy; exported globally, the legacy of this genre remains potent into the 21-century. In America, blackface is associated with minstrelsy's racial stereotypes, however it has also been repurposed by playwrights as a trenchant critique of racial politics. We will examine the history of blackface, theatrical strategies that layer new significations on the old, and its circulation abroad.
